document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

5FACD9A4535540A6806A795AB86FCB1C.description:
comparing and contrasting the Italian and the Northern Renaissance, and citing the
contributions of writers.

11631D57607541D4BDCAB32BAD3EED70.description:
citing the contributions of artists and philosophers of the Renaissance, as contrasted
with the medieval period, including Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and
Petrarch; and

696D7B6F85534A87972B262E1E06FC87.description: determining the economic and cultural foundations of the Italian Renaissance;

8085339E716144D7BD5C0235F0E76CEF.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the developments leading to
the Renaissance in Europe in terms of its impact on Western civilization by

F6DDE56731F5434BAB6FC230ADC7755F.description:
evaluating and explaining the preservation and transfer to Western Europe of
Greek, Roman, and Arabic philosophy, medicine, and science.

32C652C770C449BF9F81753F50508158.description:
explaining patterns of crisis and recovery related to the Black Death (bubonic
plague); and

9A931657B6A944A68485161B0B74A69A.description:
explaining conflicts across Europe and Asia, including the Crusades and the fall of
Constantinople;

73ED189A3965499ABCBB858FB4DF208E.description:
describing the emergence of centralized monarchies (England, France, Spain, and
Russia) and distinctive political developments in each;

15EECED7D84343D0890A8C123E274FBA.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the social, economic, and
political changes and cultural achievements in the high and late medieval periods by

70BE55ECCA22465580013FF40C0171E0.description:
evaluating and explaining the European interactions with these societies, with
emphasis on trading and economic interdependence.

7BC9DAED201A487A9DD79790BFF52419.description:
explaining the development of social, political, economic, religious, and cultural
patterns in the civilizations of the Americas; and

21B107C19FAB49EFB7FC172E87951164.description:
locating early civilizations in time and place and describing major geographic
features;

B6598BB9E3F048A5B2006C37B294EDBA.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the major civilizations of the
Western Hemisphere, including the Mayan, Aztec, and Incan, by

DEAD214AE56949B8BCAB592401FF09F6.description:
evaluating and explaining the European interactions with these societies, with
emphasis on trading and economic interdependence.

06E2C3D9489C4A13990052FEE083A5D2.description:
explaining the development of social, political, economic, religious, and cultural
patterns in each region; and

548A67B867664F1E92CB83349389451D.description:
locating early civilizations and kingdoms in time and place and describing major
geographic features;

B8396E19641B4A918B70A6DC1682A730.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the civilizations and empires
of Africa, with emphasis on the African kingdoms of Axum and Zimbabwe and the
West African civilizations of Ghana, Mali, and Songhai, by

C9B69A598A354C879A84160AD0B0FCA3.description: evaluating the impact of the Mongol Empire throughout Asia.

19B63742E66A4D538864C02219BA3207.description:
explaining the impact of Shinto and Buddhist traditions and the influence of
Chinese culture on the region; and

1FC6473B73B94BD4A7DED9C503C4512F.description:
explaining technological advances and transfers, networks of economic
interdependence, and cultural interactions;

11D23FCE79BF4776951E2505E52659A9.description: locating and explaining major global and regional trade routes;

E18B6FDE07D94648A6EBAA5D57346E51.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the civilizations and empires
of Asia, with emphasis on Japan and China, by

CE48956E8C20453B9AF70E409E07E237.description: evaluating and explaining the development of feudalism and the manor system.

CFEC549165B841248EE3C485266465A3.description: describing the social, religious, and cultural patterns of the Vikings; and

C15AA136E50141FB8A46D400D6A4F581.description:
explaining the social, religious, and cultural development of the Magyars and
Anglo-Saxons;

0D67020FC92B43E58500A352A2F93726.description:
describing the social, religious, and cultural development of the Franks, with
emphasis on the Age of Charlemagne;

371BACD37D1E4876ABE94542D4FEA5D9.description:
locating and describing the societies of Western Europe during the Middle Ages in
time and place;

40759DC8BB4C4FA78128E44D48F0AAF1.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand Western Europe during the
Middle Ages from about 500 to 1000 A.D. (C.E.) in terms of its impact on Western
civilization by

A0B4152607F6453D9D74446363C8C7A3.description:
explaining the cultural and scientific contributions and achievements of Islamic
civilization.

2EC1E8984B1D471CB80492EA4299ED75.description:
assessing the influence of geography on Islamic economic, social, and political
development, including the impact of conquest and trade; and

BB5130D4568045788D97BF5486BD0DA5.description:
describing the origin, location, beliefs, traditions, customs, and spread of Islam,
with emphasis on the Sunni-Shi’a division and the Battle of Tours;

A79B903F0045461AA771C5A3E8FA2F4E.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the Islamic civilization from
about 600 to 1000 A.D. (C.E.) by

5F7E5CD2932542F1BC44BCEE3DD282FD.description: analyzing and explaining the influence of Byzantine culture on Eastern Europe.

4DBA090DFFA7424CA2886ED32D63B78F.description:
explaining the disputes that led to the split between the Roman Catholic Church and
the Greek Orthodox Church; and

C82B2D21B5824696B5C82B38E674C2C1.description:
characterizing the role Byzantine art and architecture played in the preservation of
Greek and Roman traditions;

1D80CB8632E44FF491E0214ED495C730.description:
describing Justinian and his contributions, including the codification of Roman law,
and the expansion of the Byzantine Empire and economy;

14242B25AC8241F998488B68E6FBF73D.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the Byzantine Empire and
Eastern Europe from about 300 to 1000 A.D. (C.E.) by

BA952DEF230841D48253CEAA6002938D.description:
sequencing events related to the spread and influence of Christianity and the
Catholic Church throughout Europe.

7F63CE2715014323BDC4C80F749F1A37.description:
explaining the unifying role of the Church in Europe after the collapse of Rome;
and

D7868E658A8549EFBED28544AF6F3917.description:
describing the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs, and spread of Christianity in
time and place;

31B84BFFBD6C42E299C0A441A37F6B46.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the development of
Christianity by

0731B9A9DC6F487BAC48907F3EBA1560.description: evaluating the fall of the Western Roman Empire and the Germanic invasions.

CFF473169471417897884FA2041762A8.description:
assessing the economic structure of Rome, Rome’s imperial conquests, and the Pax
Romana; and

FCC1CF692FCF4C299F4DBAD1C379F497.description:
describing and evaluating the political structure of the Roman Empire under the rule
of Augustus Caesar;

2FD077890D384D99B82E1EA5E5203F28.description:
describing and evaluating the political and military structure of the Roman Republic
under the rule of Julius Caesar;

01C5F12951824A02BF30F659148F9E00.description: describing the social structure and cultural development of the Roman Republic;

2F7E212BC9254C68956ED46154A6A568.description: describing the social and religious structure of ancient Rome;

945A94FDDE094824B06024658FF75ECB.description:
locating Roman civilizations in time and place and describing their major
geographic features;

66EFB4FD487E4DB6BDCAA953B37F1F69.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand ancient Rome from about 700
B.C. (B.C.E.) to 500 A.D. (C.E.) in terms of its impact on Western civilization by

9D7CFE964BDD4905835073D36700C798.description:
citing and explaining contributions in drama, poetry, history, sculpture, architecture,
science, mathematics, and philosophy, with emphasis on Socrates, Plato, and
Aristotle.

B65BA99CCE4D4C03A412FB89840A6180.description:
evaluating the significance of the conquest of Greece by Macedonia and the
formation and spread of Hellenistic culture by Alexander the Great; and

0EC39DCB08E64F11BB5D81C4DE9013F0.description:
evaluating the political and economic development of Greece, with emphasis on the
Persian and Peloponnesian wars;

DE5F63579E754A2D9ABAEF3BD9974BE5.description:
describing the cultural development of Athens and Sparta, with emphasis on the
significance of citizenship and the development of democracy;

FECE4878114F442BB4164251812DE138.description: describing the social and religious structure of ancient Greece;

DA524702B8374DC593DA968A4D8021D6.description:
locating Greek civilizations in time and place and describing their major geographic
features;

3DBA75425E1C4B1C88B8D0B3D16F637E.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand ancient Greece in terms of its
impact on Western civilization by

B05822556F734DD5B0A2C0C9F189B4EB.description: describing the impact of Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism.

A17BC4D48A72407B881467FADB340724.description:
locating China in time and place, including the development of an empire and the
construction of the Great Wall; and

8B21D10EFC8F41BFA7F72BB2849C56C2.description: describing the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs, and spread of Buddhism;

79491379F46842C68E68E7E03FC7D3D4.description: describing the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs, and spread of Hinduism;

0B98FA14CC3D4BDA9F8BA99C7E3C58D3.description:
locating India in time and place, including its origins, early development, and the
debate over the Aryan migrations;

4548F7B896D54F9CBE146CDC37E3BF26.description:
locating Persia in time and place, including Zoroastrianism and the development of
an imperial bureaucracy;

39127393202248F885CC2277BB4721C0.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the civilizations of Persia,
India, and China in terms of chronology, geography, social structures, government,
economy, religion, and contributions to later civilizations by

B069B7BAB24F46978751395BACA1E4D3.description:
Classical Civilizations and Rise of Religious Traditions, 1000 B.C. (B.C.E.) to
500 A.D. (C.E.)

3D4F50983AF34287BE74B906443E5C19.description: explaining the development of language and writing.

F3E52885D9434FC69120DBBC817E40B9.description: describing the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs, and spread of Judaism; and

DC011933128B4CAB83B4687479D8323B.description: explaining the development and interactions of religious traditions;

AD233EEB90F2476C9CB874906D806619.description:
describing the development of social, political, and economic patterns, including
slavery;

86BC5F8A30054AE1A41165CCC26B5ABC.description:
locating these civilizations in time and place and describing their major geographic
features;

9746D6DCE164442DB1C24BEBAD6A6657.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the ancient river valley
civilizations, including those of Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Indus River Valley, and
China and the civilizations of the Hebrews and Phoenicians, by

CAD4A851B1164D8AA69E3828D012E9FA.description:
analyzing how archaeological discoveries are changing current understanding of
early societies.

1F0A4A50A7384A6D846CBEBD49F75E50.description:
analyzing how technological and social developments gave rise to sedentary
communities; and

AEB72B37A73D4F89BFB8D80CB7F45EC6.description:
describing characteristics of hunter-gatherer societies, including their use of tools
and fire;

AAC7120CD8794C56AEBBC4F819E730B0.description: explaining the impact of geographic environment on hunter-gatherer societies;

8886CFABB5CA47769078A7CFED07BC1D.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the period from the Paleolithic
Era to the agricultural revolution by

664AC6278EC14C66A634DEB0DAC22EF6.description: Human Origins and Early Civilizations, Prehistory to 1000 B.C. (B.C.E.)

B3E4998F86E8477D97EE839624791F94.description: investigating and researching to develop products orally and in writing.

F17A8C06199045E5AB70D7E4FABBB0C6.description:
identifying the rights and responsibilities of citizens and ethical use of materials and
intellectual property; and

4B0A0408E57B4CCBABF14C583D2CE9DA.description:
using a decision-making model to analyze and explain the incentives for and
consequences of a specific choice made;

F9FD38EEFD75482BA5B51646CA9CCD05.description: analyzing multiple connections across time and place;

383667A23F3F4FC587B61F591BD1085F.description:
explaining how indirect cause-and-effect relationships impacted people, places, and
events in world history;

B35F4C05CE0549DB8ADB0BAC4D1AA890.description:
comparing and contrasting historical, cultural, economic, and political perspectives
in world history;

7D70F74344EE40E5AE2FC5D8643D257A.description: evaluating sources for accuracy, credibility, bias, and propaganda;

92C5F03C8EA54B3EBBCBD14867583E76.description:
interpreting charts, graphs, and pictures to determine characteristics of people,
places, or events in world history;

8C9A8250E93C4F36B6E124A1DC7532B9.description:
using geographic information to determine patterns and trends to understand world
history;

6A4B3D219067483FB3CB53232E3A1D95.description:
synthesizing evidence from artifacts and primary and secondary sources to obtain
information about events in world history;

7EAE41CE627A4801856BE8E87A3E59B6.description:
The student will demonstrate skills for historical thinking, geographical analysis,
economic decision making, and responsible citizenship by
